title: fix: handling of S3 part-level checksums
body:
## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here -->
aws-sdk-rust#764

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
If `GetObject` response has checksum value ending with `-#` where `#` is an integer between 1 and 10000, clients **MUST** skip checksum validation. A checksum ending with `-#` indicates that `GetObject` returned a whole, multipart object. Clients can not validate such checksums, as they are checksums of checksums, and not the actual object.

See [this page](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/userguide/checking-object-integrity.html#large-object-checksums) for more information

## Testing
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
Tests are included in the PR.

title: Remove `ProtocolTraitImplGenerator` from `codegen-core`
body:
## Motivation and Context
The `ProtocolTraitImplGenerator` was originally an implementation detail for client protocol codegen that ended up getting copied into `codegen-core`. With the work to move towards an orchestrator approach for client codegen, this interface needs to change for clients specifically, and thus, it needs to be removed from core in order to not affect the server codegen.

title: Add support for omitting session token in canonical requests
body:
## Motivation and Context
Some services require the session token to be omitted from the canonical request when calculating the signature. For additional context, see https://github.com/awslabs/aws-sdk-rust/issues/477

## Description
This PR extends the signing settings with `omit_session_token` such that the security token only gets added after a signature has been calculated as is required by some services: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/create-signed-request.html#add-signature-to-request

The security token is now added after the signature is calculated, if the new setting states so.

## Testing
Two new tests have been added to cover:
1. `SessionTokenMode::Exclude` is synonomous to a session token that is `None`
2. If a session token is provided and `SessionTokenMode::Exclude` is set, the token is excluded in the signing process, but kept as a header in the mutated request
3. `SessionTokenMode::Include` is the default and is the behavior as it was prior to this PR.

----

_By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice._

title: Fix test failure in `no-default-features`
body:
## Motivation and Context
This PR fixes a test failure from `test_clients_from_sdk_config`. The test failure has prevented us from releasing a new version of `aws-sdk-rust`.

## Description
It is a negative test expecting a panic, but it failed because it panicked for a different reason, i.e. `no default sleep implementation available` instead of `No HTTP connector was available...`. The fix will add a default async sleep to a service config to ensure that the panic occurs for the expected reason.

title: Feature: Add smithy orchestrator
body:
[See the RFC for more details](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/pull/2439)

This PR adds a new, common framework for constructing client requests and handling service responses. My intentions are to:

- Improve the user experience by
- Simplifying several aspects of sending a request
- Adding more extension points to the request/response lifecycle
- Improve the maintainer experience by
- Making our SDK more similar in structure to other AWS SDKs
- Simplifying many aspects of the request/response lifecycle
- Making room for future changes

Additionally, functionality that we currently provide like retries, logging, and auth with be incorporated into this new process in such a way as to make it more configurable and understandable.

_By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice._

title: Add connection poisoning to aws-smithy-client
body:
## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
- https://github.com/awslabs/aws-sdk-rust/issues/160
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here -->

## Description
Built on top of two changes to Hyper, this adds the concept of connection poisoning to Smithy client. To do this, we needed machinery to get access to the "connection metadata" used by the request. This is done in a connector agnostic way with the `CaptureSmithyConnection` bridge.

A separate layer considers the error classification then invokes poison as necessary. To support testing this, `WireLeveMock` was created, a mocking facility that binds to 0.0.0.0.

For AWS services, this behavior is **enabled by default**. For generic-smithy clients, this behavior is **disabled by default**.

## Testing
- integration test in S3
- detailed tests of specific behavior in aws-smithy-client

## Checklist
<!--- If a checkbox below is not applicable, then please DELETE it rather than leaving it unchecked -->

title: Make service builder handler setters more flexible
body:
## Motivation and Context

The signature of the handler setters on the service builder restricted the extractors used by the model service to be identical to the extractors on the handler. This meant that any middleware applied to the handler could not make use of extractors not included in the handler.

## Description

- Add additional type parameter to the service builder handler setter.

title: Use a bespoke version of `Either`
body:
## Motivation and Context

https://docs.rs/tower/latest/tower/util/enum.Either.html

> Both services must be of the same request, response, and error types.

This is not the case, the error types are not required to be the same - as seen in the actual [`Service` implementation](https://docs.rs/tower/latest/tower/util/enum.Either.html#impl-Service%3CRequest%3E). The `tower::util::Either` instead takes either error and converts it to `Box<dyn Error>` which is not the intended behavior and conflicts with the contract of Smithy which wants either `Infallible` in the case of a HTTP middleware and `Op::Error` in the case of a model middleware.

## Description

- Roll bespoke version of `Either` which preserves error.
- Add `Plugin` implementation for `Plugin`.
- Use bespoke `Either` for `FilterByOperationName`.

title: RFC: Smithy Orchestrator
body:
This RFC proposes a new process for constructing client requests and handling service responses. This new process is intended to:

- Improve the user experience by
- Simplifying several aspects of sending a request
- Adding more extension points to the request/response lifecycle
- Improve the maintainer experience by
- Making our SDK more similar in structure to other AWS SDKs
- Simplifying many aspects of the request/response lifecycle
- Making room for future changes

Additionally, functionality that the SDKs currently provide like retries, logging, and auth with be incorporated into this new process in such a way as to make it more configurable and understandable.

This RFC references but is not the source of truth on:

- Interceptors: To be described in depth in a future RFC.
- Runtime Plugins: To be described in depth in a future RFC.

----

Addresses https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/issues/1759 (those that are not checked off)
Addresses https://github.com/awslabs/aws-sdk-rust/issues/600

## Description
This commit adds more client re-exports. Specifically, it re-exports the following types:
- `aws_smithy_http::body::SdkBody`
- `aws_smithy_http::byte_stream::error::Error` (re-exported as `ByteStreamError`)
- `aws_smithy_http::operation::{Request, Response}`

title: Add hook for CodegenDecorators to insert a custom symbol provider
body:
## Motivation and Context
https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/issues/2158

## Description
This provides a new hook on the `CoreCodegenDecorator` interface. This allows authors of custom decorators (like myself) to manipulate symbols when they are being built.

For example -- this allows me to insert extra derives (such as `serde::Deserialize`).

## Testing
* Ensured all tests are passing locally `./gradlew test`
* Rebuilt the package with my custom decorator and verified my decorator receives the expected callback.

## Checklist
No updates to changelog. This is an internal change that shouldn't affect most users.

title: Make codegen diff fault tolerant
body:
## Motivation and Context
With https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/pull/2149 we started compiling Rust crate for Python examples to generate codegen diff. This causes the whole CI step and bot to failure if there is a compilation error on the example Python service (as you can see at https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/actions/runs/4298366241/jobs/7492418589).
This PR makes codegen diff for Python service fault tolerant, meaning even if the code fails to compile the bot will still be able to submit codegen diff without any issue.

## Testing
I'll push a change that'll break generated Python code to see if bot behaves correctly.

You can see that compilation of the crate failed: https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/actions/runs/4315955093/jobs/7531098939#step:3:2009 
but the bot still posted the diffs: https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/pull/2426#issuecomment-1452161201

----

title: Fix Inaccurate documentation on ProfileFileCredentialsProvider
body:
## Motivation and Context
Fixes https://github.com/awslabs/aws-sdk-rust/issues/746.

## Description
The doc previously described that `ProfileFileCredentialsProvider` would reload and reparse the profile from the file system every time it was called. The current behavior is loading & parsing happen only for the first the provider is called and the parsed file contents will be [cached indefinitely](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/blob/main/aws/rust-runtime/aws-config/src/provider_config.rs#L46).

----

title: Add support for the awsQueryCompatible trait
body:
## Motivation and Context
Implements https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/issues/1872

## Description
This PR adds support for the [awsQueryCompatible](https://smithy.io/2.0/aws/protocols/aws-query-protocol.html?#aws-protocols-awsquerycompatible-trait) trait to the Rust SDK. The trait is specifically used with the `awsJson1_0` trait (`awsQueryCompatible`'s Trait selector is `service [trait|awsJson1_0]`) and allows services to continue supporting a custom error code via the [awsQueryError](https://awslabs.github.io/smithy/2.0/aws/protocols/aws-query-protocol.html#aws-protocols-awsqueryerror-trait) trait when they switch from `awsQuery` to `awsJson1_0` annotated with `awsQueryCompatible`.

When a service makes that protocol switch, the service will then respond with an additional header `x-amzn-query-error` whose value is in the form of `<error code>;<error type>`. An example looks something like
```
HTTP/1.1 400
x-amzn-query-error: AWS.SimpleQueueService.NonExistentQueue;Sender
Date: Wed, 08 Sep 2021 23:46:52 GMT
Content-Type: application/x-amz-json-1.0
Content-Length: 163

{
    "__type": "com.amazonaws.sqs#QueueDoesNotExist",
    "message": "some user-visible message"
}
```
(`AWS.SimpleQueueService.NonExistentQueue` corresponds to `error code` and `Sender` to `error type`)

The goal of this PR is to allow customers to have access to `error code` and `error type`, given a response like above (see [CHANGE.next.toml](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/pull/2398/commits/fdd98b1403e1d345b58025be9e98ee96e026074e) for more details). The code changes, therefore, include
- Check whether a service is annotated with both `awsJson1_0` annotated with `awsQueryCompatible`.
- If so, create a new class for `AwsQueryCompatible` to generate code for parsing a response to extract `error code` and `error type` from the custom header `x-amzn-query-error`.
- Make `error code` and `error type` available in `ErrorMetadata`.

## Testing
- [x] Added unit tests in `rust-runtime/inlineable/src/aws_query_compatible_errors.rs`
- [x] Added unit tests in `AwsQueryCompatibleTest.kt`
  - [x] Validated SDK can parse error code and error type fields
  - [x] Validated SDK can handle missing custom header (hence there is no `<error code>;<error type>`), still being able to obtain error code from the JSON payload instead.
- [x] Passed tests in CI

## Checklist
<!--- If a checkbox below is not applicable, then please DELETE it rather than leaving it unchecked -->
- [x] I have updated `CHANGELOG.next.toml` if I made changes to the smithy-rs codegen or runtime crates

----

_By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice._

title: Add builder symbol/module resolution to symbol providers
body:
## Motivation and Context
Builder structs, while unmodeled, are integral to inputs, outputs, errors, and modeled types, and this should be reflected in the design in the `codegen-core` module by placing them front and center in the symbol provider interface like we do for operation errors. Individual code generators can replace builder codegen, but referring to a builder should be centralized.

This PR also allows the `ModuleProvider` to provide modules for builders, which is required for implementing [RFC-26](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/blob/main/design/src/rfcs/rfc0026_client_crate_organization.md).

----

title: Ensure cache miss logging should be displayed the right number of times in concurrent setting
body:
## Motivation and Context
This commit ensures that logging for cache miss should be displayed properly when multiple threads execute `cache.get_or_load` concurrently ([here](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/blob/main/aws/rust-runtime/aws-credential-types/src/cache/lazy_caching.rs#L84-L115)). Specifically, the log line for cache miss should be displayed only once for the first thread that succeeds in populating a cache value.

## Description
We observed that the following log was emitted while running canary:
```
2023-02-15T19:59:29.864953Z  INFO run_canaries:run_canary{name="transcribe_canary"}: aws_credential_types::cache::lazy_caching: credentials cache miss occurred; retrieved new AWS credentials (took 1.703708ms)
2023-02-15T19:59:29.864986Z  INFO run_canaries:run_canary{name="ec2_paginator"}: aws_credential_types::cache::lazy_caching: credentials cache miss occurred; retrieved new AWS credentials (took 1.703083ms)
2023-02-15T19:59:29.876153Z  INFO run_canaries:run_canary{name="s3"}:lazy_load_credentials: aws_config::profile::credentials: constructed abstract provider from config file chain=ProfileChain { base: AccessKey(Credentials { provider_name: "ProfileFile", ... }), chain: [] }
2023-02-15T19:59:29.876225Z  INFO run_canaries:run_canary{name="s3"}:lazy_load_credentials: aws_config::profile::credentials::exec: first credentials will be loaded from AccessKey(Credentials { provider_name: "ProfileFile", ... }) base=AccessKey(Credentials { provider_name: "ProfileFile", ... })
2023-02-15T19:59:29.876326Z  INFO run_canaries:run_canary{name="s3"}:lazy_load_credentials: aws_config::profile::credentials: loaded base credentials creds=Credentials { provider_name: "ProfileFile", ... }
2023-02-15T19:59:29.876397Z  INFO run_canaries:run_canary{name="s3"}: aws_credential_types::cache::lazy_caching: credentials cache miss occurred; retrieved new AWS credentials (took 392.916µs)
```
This is a case where three threads are concurrently executing `cache.get_or_load`, which can happen because there is a race between a cache lookup and putting a value in the cache so all threads can come to the [else](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/blob/main/aws/rust-runtime/aws-credential-types/src/cache/lazy_caching.rs#L78) block.

That said, ideally we should see `credentials cache miss occurred;` only once for a thread that succeeds in populating credentials in the cache but we actually see it three times in the log above. Prior to the PR, a call to [info!](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/blob/main/aws/rust-runtime/aws-credential-types/src/cache/lazy_caching.rs#L116-L119) displaying `credentials cache miss occurred;` was outside of `cache.get_or_load`. What this means is even though the `transcribe_canary` thread and the `ec2_paginator` thread did not end up executing the lambda passed to `cache.get_or_load` (because the thread `s3` went ahead and executed it, populating credentials in the cache), they still executed the line of code for `info!`

The code change in the PR addresses this.

Lastly, we have left `debug!` where we used to call `info!`.  This is because if we completely removed `info!` and left nothing behind, then we would lose log lines for `run_canaries:run_canary{name="transcribe_canary"}:` and `run_canaries:run_canary{name="ec2_paginator"}:` in the snippet above. (it's `debug!` to be in sync with [that in the cache hit](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/blob/main/aws/rust-runtime/aws-credential-types/src/cache/lazy_caching.rs#L75) case).

----

_By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice._

title: Remove `toEnumVariantName` from `RustSymbolProvider`
body:
## Motivation and Context
The `toEnumVariantName` function existed on symbol provider to work around enum definitions not being shapes. In the future when we refactor to use `EnumShape` instead of `EnumTrait`, there will be `MemberShape`s for each enum member. This change incrementally moves us to that future by creating fake `MemberShape`s in the enum generator from the enum definition.

~This change should have no codegen diff.~ The server codegen diff reveals that this improves doc comments emitted by the `UnionGenerator`.

----

_By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice._

title: Disallow `@uniqueItems`-constrained list shapes that reach a map shape
body:
The server SDK codegen generates Rust code that does not compile when a
`@uniqueItems`-constrained list shape reaches a map shape, essentially
because `std::collections::HashMap` does not implement
`std::hash::Hash`.

A ticket with the Smithy team was opened in awslabs/smithy#1567 to
disallow such models.

This commit makes it so that codegen aborts with an informative message
when such models are encountered, instead of going ahead and producing
code that does not compile.

This commit also slightly adjusts the error messages produced when
unsupported constraint traits are found.

----

_By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice._

title: Fix: native-tls client creation to support HTTPS again
body:
## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here -->
aws-sdk-rust#736

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
- **update:** use `enforce_http = false` when creating `native-tls` hyper connector
- **refactor:** move smithy `conns` module to its own file
- **add:** sanity tests ensuring we can make HTTP and HTTPS requests with the `rustls` and `native-tls` connectors
- **remove:** `use crate::*` imports in favor of explicit imports

## Testing
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->
wrote 4 tests
